p5.serialport.name: p5.serialport
p5.serialport.description: Base class for a serial port. Creates an instance of the serial library and prints "hostname":"serverPort" in the console.

p5.SerialPort.name: p5.SerialPort
p5.SerialPort.description: Base class for a serial port. Creates an instance of the serial library and prints "hostname":"serverPort" in the console.

params.name: hostname
params.description: Name of the host. Defaults to 'localhost'.

example: var portName = '/dev/cu.usbmodem1411'; //enter your portName function setup() { createCanvas(400, 300); serial = new p5.SerialPort() serial.open(portName); }

classitems.description:
p5.serialport
Shawn Van Every (Shawn.Van.Every@nyu.edu)
ITP/NYU
LGPL

https://github.com/vanevery/p5.serialport
Tells you whether p5 is connected to the serial port.
classitems.name: isConnected
example: var serial; // variable to hold an instance of the serialport library var portName = '/dev/cu.usbmodem1411'; function setup() { createCanvas(400, 300); serial = new p5.SerialPort(); serial.open(portName); println(serial.isConnected()); }

classitems.description:
Lists serial ports available to the server.
Synchronously returns cached list, asynchronously returns updated list via callback.
Must be called within the p5 setup() function.
Doesn't work with the p5 editor's "Run in Browser" mode.
classitems.name: list
example:
function setup() { createCanvas(windowWidth, windowHeight); serial = new p5.SerialPort(); serial.list(); serial.open("/dev/cu.usbmodem1411"); }
For full example: Link
function printList(portList) { // portList is an array of serial port names for (var i = 0; i < portList.length; i++) { // Display the list the console: println(i + " " + portList[i]); } }

classitems.description:
Opens the serial port to enable data flow.
Use the {[serialOptions]} parameter to set the baudrate if it's different from the p5 default, 9600.
classitems.name: open

params.name: serialPort
params.description: Name of the serial port, something like '/dev/cu.usbmodem1411'

params.name: serialOptions
params.description:
Object with optional options as {key: value} pairs.
                               Options include 'baudrate'.

example:
// Change this to the name of your arduino's serial port serial.open("/dev/cu.usbmodem1411");
// All of the following are valid: serial.open(portName); serial.open(portName, {}, onOpen); serial.open(portName, {baudrate: 9600}, onOpen) function onOpen() { print('opened the serial port!'); }

classitems.description: Sends a byte to a webSocket server which sends the same byte out through a serial port.
classitems.name: write

params.name: data
params.description: Writes bytes, chars, ints, bytes[], and strings to the serial port.

classitems.description:
Returns a number between 0 and 255 for the next byte that's waiting in the buffer. 
Returns -1 if there is no byte, although this should be avoided by first checking available() to see if data is available.
classitems.name: read

return.description: Value of the byte waiting in the buffer. Returns -1 if there is no byte.

example:
function serialEvent() { inByte = int(serial.read()); byteCount++; }
function serialEvent() { // read a byte from the serial port: var inByte = serial.read(); // store it in a global variable: inData = inByte; }

classitems.description: Returns the next byte in the buffer as a char.
classitems.name: readChar

return.description: Value of the Unicode-code unit character byte waiting in the buffer, converted from bytes. Returns -1 or 0xffff if there is no byte.

example: var inData; function setup() { // callback for when new data arrives serial.on('data', serialEvent); function serialEvent() { // read a char from the serial port: inData = serial.readChar(); }

classitems.description:
Returns a number between 0 and 255 for the next byte that's waiting in the buffer, and then clears the buffer of data.
If there's no data in the buffer initially, returns -1, although this should be avoided by first checking available() to see if data is available.
classitems.name: read

return.description: Value of the byte waiting in the buffer. Returns -1 if there is no byte.

example: var inData; function setup() { // callback for when new data arrives serial.on('data', serialEvent); function serialEvent() { // read bytes from the serial port: inData = serial.readBytes(); }

classitems.description:
Returns all of the data available, up to and including a particular character.
If the character isn't in the buffer, 'null' is returned. 
The version without the byteBuffer parameter returns a byte array of all data up to and including the interesting byte. 
This is not efficient, but is easy to use. 

The version with the byteBuffer parameter is more efficient in terms of time and memory. 
It grabs the data in the buffer and puts it into the byte array passed in and returns an integer value for the number of bytes read. 
If the byte buffer is not large enough, -1 is returned and an error is printed to the message area. 
If nothing is in the buffer, 0 is returned.
classitems.name: readBytesUntil
example: // All of the following are valid: charToFind.charCodeAt(); charToFind.charCodeAt(0); charToFind.charCodeAt(0, );

classitems.description:
Returns all the data from the buffer as a String. 
This method assumes the incoming characters are ASCII. 
If you want to transfer Unicode data: first, convert the String to a byte stream in the representation of your choice (i.e. UTF8 or two-byte Unicode data). 
Then, send it as a byte array.
classitems.name: readString

classitems.description: Returns all of the data available as an ASCII-encoded string.
classitems.name: readStringUntil

return.description: ASCII-encoded string until and not including the stringToFind.

classitems.description: Returns all of the data available as an ASCII-encoded string until a line break is encountered.
classitems.name: readLine

return.description: All of the data available as an ASCII-encoded string until a line break is encountered

classitems.description: Returns the number of bytes available.
classitems.name: available

return.description: The length of the serial buffer array, in terms of number of bytes in the buffer.

classitems.description: Returns the last byte of data from the buffer.
classitems.name: last

classitems.description: Returns the last byte of data from the buffer as a char.
classitems.name: lastChar

classitems.description:
Stops data communication on this port. 
Use to shut the connection when you're finished with the Serial.
classitems.name: stop

classitems.description: Tell server to close the serial port. This functions the same way as serial.on('close', portClose).
classitems.name: close
example: var inData; function setup() { serial.open(portOpen); serial.close(portClose); } function portOpen() { println('The serial port is open.'); } function portClose() { println('The serial port closed.'); }
